Topic: Law
Context: A loading dock consists of exactly six bays numbered 1 through 6 consecutively from one side of the dock to the other. Each bay is holding a different one of exactly six types of cargoâ€”fuel, grain, livestock, machinery, produce, or textiles. The following apply: The bay holding grain has a higher number than the bay holding livestock. The bay holding livestock has a higher number than the bay holding textiles. The bay holding produce has a higher number than the bay holding fuel. The bay holding textiles is next to the bay holding produce.
Question: Which one of the following CANNOT be the type of cargo held in bay 4?
Choices:
  A: grain
  B: livestock
  C: machinery
  D: produce
  E: textiles
Reflection:

Then you reflected on the problem, your solution, and the correct answer.
Use your self-reflection (below) to help you answer this question.
Any information that you are not allowed to see will be marked [REDACTED].

Thought:
The bay holding grain has a higher number than the bay holding livestock, so grain cannot be in bay 1.
The bay holding livestock has a higher number than the bay holding textiles, so livestock cannot be in bay 1 or 2, and textiles cannot be in bay 1.
The bay holding produce has a higher number than the bay holding fuel, so produce cannot be in bay 1, and fuel cannot be in bay 1 or 2.
The bay holding textiles is next to the bay holding produce, so textiles cannot be in bay 6, and produce cannot be in bay 1 or 6.
Since bay 4 is in the middle, it cannot hold a type of cargo that must be at one end or the other.
Action: Answer("E") (Textiles cannot be in bay 4 because it must be next to produce, and produce cannot be in bay 1 or 6, so textiles cannot be in bay 4.)
